clinical_study.brief_title: Perceptions and Prevalence of Workplace Violence in Healthcare
clinical_study.official_title: Perceptions and Prevalence of Workplace Violence in Healthcare

brief_summary.textblock: Workplace violence includes physical and verbal aggression as well as threatening behavior. All types of workplace violence incidents in health care are often under-reported, especially if there is no lasting physical injury.

detailed_description.textblock: Research reveals that healthcare workers are three times more likely to experience workplace violence than any other occupation. The first step toward reducing the occurrence of violence is to understand the perceptions and prevalence of workplace violence.

primary_outcome.measure: Level and type of workplace violence
primary_outcome.description: Research Instruments Survey Questionnaire used to measure physical and psychological characteristics of violence at work
Self-reported consequences in relation to work (e.g., distress/burnout, transfer/quits, absenteeism, financial situation, career path)

secondary_outcome.description: Survey Monkey will be used to measured Frequency of reported incidents concerning the different forms of violence at work

secondary_outcome.measure: Self-reported impact of violence on quality of care for patients
secondary_outcome.description: Impact on the organization (e.g., cost data, lost work days, staff fluctuation, staff shortage)

arm_group.description: All MHS employees, clinical and non-clinical.

intervention.description: The subjects will complete a survey related to workplace violance.

study_pop.textblock: Participants must be employed full-time, part-time, or per diem (PRN) by the acute care organization (MDMC, MCMC, MMMC, MSMC, MLMC) at the time of study data collection. All staff, both clinical and non-clinical, are eligible to participate. Participants must be able to read English.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Participants must be employed full-time, part-time, or per diem
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to read English will cause a staff member to be excluded from the study, as the survey is written in English.
